title: HETEROCHROMATIN AND SEX-CHROMOSOME VARIATION IN BATS OF THE GENUS CAROLLIA (CHIROPTERA: PHYLLOSTOMIDAE)
abstract: comparing two proportions in 2 x 2 contingency tables. Technometrics, 19:145-157. MICHENER, G. R. 1983. Kin identification, matriarches, and the evolution of sociality in grounddwelling sciurids. Pp. 528-572, in Advances in the study of mammalian behavior 0. F. Eisenberg and D. G. Kleiman, eds.). Spec. abstract.text: comparing two proportions in 2 x 2 contingency tables. Technometrics, 19:145-157. MICHENER, G. R. 1983. Kin identification, matriarches, and the evolution of sociality in grounddwelling sciurids. Pp. 528-572, in Advances in the study of mammalian behavior 0. F. Eisenberg and D. G. Kleiman, eds.). Spec. Publ., Amer. Soc. Mamm., 7:1-753. NOVAK, J. M. 1983. Multiple captures of Peromyscus leucopus: social behavior in a small rodent. J.

body_text.text: Specimens for this study were collected from natural populations and deposited in the Texas Cooperative Wildlife Collection and the Carnegie Museum of Natural History. Field karyotype numbers (AK prefix) are listed for each specimen. Exact collecting localities for individuals examined are as follows: C. castanea, Costa Rica: Heredia; 2.5 km SE Puerto Viejo (AK7049 &); Peru: Huanuco, Leoncia Prado Prov.; 2 km S Tingo Maria (AK8051 !t, AK8052 !t, AK8053 &). C. perspicillata, Costa Rica: Guanacaste; Finca La Pacifica (AK7007 &); Costa Rica: Heredia; 2 km SE Puerto Viejo (AK7048 !t). Fibroblast cultures were initiated from ear biopsies and grown in Hams F-I0 with 20% fetal-bovine serum at 35°C. Actively dividing cultures were harvested without use of a mitotic inhibitor, treated with 0.075M KCI for 35 min at 35°C, fixed in methanol: acetic acid (3: 1) and air dried on glass slides. C-bands were produced by modifications of the technique of Sumner (1972) . Q-banding (Caspersson et aI. , 1969) was performed by staining slides in a quinacrine dihydrochloride solution (1 mg/ 50 ml H20) for 10 min. Hoechst 33258 (Latt, 1973) and DAPI (4, 6-diamidino-2-phenylindole; Schweizer, 1976) staining was performed by immersing slides for 45 min in 40 ml of 4°C distilled H20 into which was added 5-10 drops of either DAPI (1 mg DAPI/ 30 ml absolute ethanol) or Hoechst 33258 (1 mg Hoechst 33258/ 30 ml absolute ethanol) stock solutions. Quinacrine-, DAPI-and Hoechst-33258-stained slides were covered using glycerine as the mounting medium. Replication banding using 5bromo-2'-deoxyuridine (BrdU) was performed as described previously (Tucker, 1986) . A Leitz Orthoplan microscope was used for both brightfield and fluorescence microscopy.

The C-band karyotypes (Fig. la) of our specimens of C. perspicillata are identical to those reported for this species by other researchers (Pathak et aI. , 1973; Stock, 1975) . All autosomes have pericentromeric heterochromatin. The large metacentric autosome pair 1 has an interstitial band of heterochromatin on the short arm. The two large subtelocentric autosome pairs 2 and 3 have large blocks of heterochromatin near the telomeres of the short arms and on the long arms adjacent to the centromeres. The medium-sized submetacentric autosome pair 5 has a large heterochromatic block at the telomere of the short arm. The X chromosome has both centromeric and short-arm telomeric heterochromatin. The YI appears entirely heterochromatic and the Yz has centromeric heterochromatin.

Fluorescent staining of metaphase chromosomes of these same specimens revealed heterogeneity within the C-band heterochromatin (Fig. 2) . Certain regions of heterochromatin fluoresced brightly when stained with quinacrine dihydrochloride (Q-bands). The Q-bright regions ( Fig. 2a ) corresponded to the heterochromatic regions of the interstitial band on chromosome 1, the telomeric bands of chromosomes 2 and 3, the heterochromatic short armof chromosome -5, the telomeric band on the short arm of the X, and most of the Note the presence of bright fluorescent regions on autosomes 1, 2, 3, 5, and the X. These are best visualized with quinacrine, less well with DAPI, and not evident with Hoechst 33258.

Yj chromosome. These same heterochromatic regions were less distinct when stained with DAPI ( Fig. 2b ) and did not fluoresce brightly when stained with Hoechst 33258 (Fig. 2c) . The centromeric C-bands did not fluoresce differentially with any of the fluorochromes.

Replication banding of mitotic metaphases confirms the findings of Pathak et al. (1973) who studied this species with autoradiographic techniques. Constitutive heterochromatin and the allocyclic X replicate late in the S-phase (Fig. 3) . The autosome translocated to the X, however, replicates early.

The karyotype of the Costa Rican population of C. castanea is identical to that of C. perspicillata described herein (Patton and Gardner, 1971 ). The C-band patterns of Costa Rican C. castanea are nearly identical to C. perspicillata both in size and position of the C-positive regions (Fig. lc) . Major differences are absence of the interstitial C-positive region on chromosome 1 present in C. perspicillata and presence of a C-positive heterochromatic short arm on chromosome 6 in C. castanea absent in C. perspicillata. C. castanea differs from C. perspicillata by the absence of Q-bright heterochromatic regions. In addition, there are no bright fluorescent regions when metaphases are stained with DAPI or Hoechst 33258.

The karyotypes of our Peruvian specimens of C. castanea are identical to that reported by Patton and Gardner (1971) . Peruvian C. castanea differs from C. perspicillata and Costa Rican C. castanea in diploid number. C. castanea from Peru has a pair of medium-sized acrocentric autosomes that correspond to both the Y 2 and the distal portion of the long arm of the X in Costa Rican C. castanea and in C. perspicillata. C-band patterns are identical between the two populations of C. castanea with exception of the X chromosome. In C. castanea from Peru, the short-arm telomeric region of the X chromosome lacks C-band heterochromatin (Fig. Ib) .

Fluorescent-chromosome banding patterns (quinacrine, DAPI, Hoechst 33258) of C. castanea from Peru are identical to those of C. castanea from Costa Rica. There are no brightly fluorescent regions on any chromosome (Fig. 4) . The replication-banding patterns of C. castanea from Peru indicate that the heterochromatin of the autosomes and the Y chromosome replicate late in S-phase. The allocyclic X also replicates late in S-phase but an early replicating region on the short arm of the X was evident in some cells.

Although differences in the distribution of heterochromatin between C. castanea and C. perspicillata involve only two autosomal pairs of chromosomes, there is a striking difference in fluorescent banding patterns between these two species (Fig. 4) . The C-band heterochromatic regions of C. castanea exhibit low levels of fluorescence when stained with quinacrine or DAPI, whereas all interstitial and telomeric C-band heterochromatic regions of C. perspicillata fluoresce brightly (Fig. 4) . The differences in quinacrine-and DAPI-Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmammal/article/70/1/174/902035 by University of Michigan user on 07 October 2021  FIG. 3. -Late-replicating regions stained differentially with acridine orange in 5-bromo-2'-deoxyuridine labelled chromosomes of a female Carollia perspicillata. Note the late-replicating original X portion of the compound X (lightly stained region). The autosomal portion of the compound X is early replicating (darkly stained region). Late-replicating regions (lightly stained) corresponding to the C-band heterochromatin are present in autosomes. staining patterns clearly indicate variation in the base sequence of heterochromatin between these two species. Quinacrine dihydrochloride binds to DNA by intercalation between the base pairs and fluorescence is enhanced by short stretches of DNA rich in adenine and thymine base pairs (Comings, 1978) . DAPI and Hoechst 33258 fluorescence also is enhanced by adenine-and thymine-rich DNA, but the mode of binding to DNA differs from that of quinacrine. Both DAPI and Hoechst 33258 bind externally in the minor groove of DNA with binding dependent upon the presence of adenine and thymine base pairs. However, one DAPI molecule covers three base pairs whereas one Hoechst 33258 molecule covers four (Dervan, 1986; Manzini et ai., 1983) . Thus, the three dyes used in this study yield different banding patterns because variation in adenine and thymine richness at certain chromosomal locations among the taxa result in different degrees of fluorescence enhancement. Although it can be concluded tentatively that the bright-fluorescent regions of C. perspicillata are adenine and thymine rich relative to the same sites in C. castanea, the possible role that chromosomal proteins play in quinacrine fluorescence (Comings, 1978) requires that this conclusion be drawn cautiously. In this respect, the C-band heterochromatin of C. perspicillata resembles the quinacrinebrilliant regions of certain apes (Pongidae) and man (Miller, 1977) rather than the C-bands of the laboratory mouse (Mus). The latter fluoresce brightly when stained with Hoechst 33258 (Seth and Gropp, 1973) .

The pattern of variation in heterochromatic DNA sequences between C. perspicillata and C. castanea suggests that these sequences have evolved in a "concerted" manner (Dover et ai., 1982) within each taxon. Concerted evolution of a set of DNA sequences dispersed throughout a genome is characterized by greater sequence homogeneity within species than among species. The presence of Q-bright heterochromatin dispersed throughout the genome of C. perspicillata is suggestive of intraspecific homogeneity of a set of heterochromatic DNA sequences, although DNA-sequence data are required for definite confirmation. Moreover, the absence of Q-bright heterochromatic DNA in the closely related species C. castanea documents interspecific heterogeneity.

The DNA-replication patterns using BrdU-labelled chromosomes stained with acridine orange are consistent with the findings of Pathak et ai. (1973) who demonstrated that heterochromatin in C. perspicillata replicated later than euchromatin in S-phase. These findings are herein extended to C. castanea from Peru. The replication-banding patterns in this species confirmed the absence of an interstitial band of heterochromatin on chromosome 1. In addition, the centromeric late-replicating region of chromosome 1 is larger in C. perspicillata than in C. castanea. This is not obvious from the C-band patterns of these two species.

FIG. 4.-Haploid karyotypes of (columns left to right) C-bands and Q-bands of C. perspicillata (Cp) and Q-bands and C-bands of C. castanea (Cc) from Peru. Note the presence of Q-bright heterochromatin on chromosomes 1, 2, 3, 5, X, and Yj (the real Y) in C. perspicillata, all of which are absent in C. castanea. Pathak et al. (1973) also documented the composite nature of the X chromosome of C. perspicillata by demonstrating that the allocyclic X of females replicated differentially. Replication banding of C. castanea from Peru documented the absence of autosomal chromatin on the long arm of the X.

The use of fluorescent dyes with differing DNA-binding specificities and use of replication banding by a fluorescent-staining protocol have elucidated chromosomal variation in the genus Carollia beyond the resolution of G-and C-banding. In this manner, fluorescent-banding techniques provide an important tool to enhance understanding of patterns of chromosomal change in evolution.
